Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Backpropagation and NEAT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=82117382; y=aTXtaCvMGAuly3rJVCtSGrlt2bNJaiWk9GL74nAoMNhzw9H3gn1Q242eYw

Ken,

Most excellently said.


Carl,

Like Ken, I invite you to put your time/money where your words are.


Jim


Kenneth Stanley wrote:
>
> Andy, let me make you a prediction: If you pursue the research
> direction that you believe in, and I pursue the one that I believe in,
> the world will be a better place than if we all tried to do exactly
> the same thing. That is the beauty of research. But the way to make
> something happen in research, the way to convince people of a point of
> view, is simply to do it. Why not give your theory a shot? By all
> means, broadening the applicability of NEAT and HyperNEAT would be
> great. If you have a theory on how to do it, you have my full support.
>
> ken
>
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com>, "afcarl2" 
> <a.carl@...> wrote:
> >
> > Ken,
> >
> > I believe it would be beneficial to others contemplating usage of
> > NEAT, to prominently label what your "individually favored" version
> > of NEAT/HyperNEAT is. Namely, unconstrained mono-objective search.
> > This way it will enable them to more quickly identify if it is
> > consistent with there requirements, embrace it or continue looking.
> >
> > FYI, "physics-based surrogate models" is to surrogate models, what
> > NEAT is to AI. One part of a much larger whole. Its evident that you
> > did not "see the deeper connection" intended. That's unfortunate,
> > since I believe the applicability of NEAT and HyperNEAT would be
> > profoundly broadened.
> >
> >
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com>, 
> "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Andy, I fully appreciate your enthusiasm for engineering
> > optimization
> > > and operations research. In fact, I am not unaware of this area
> > and
> > > have looked into "physics-based surrogate models." Here is a nice
> > > paper on the subject:
> > >
> > > http://www.cs.sandia.gov/DAKOTA/papers/OUU_MAO2004.pdf 
> <http://www.cs.sandia.gov/DAKOTA/papers/OUU_MAO2004.pdf>
> > >
> > > Nevertheless, I still see no concrete connection to HyperNEAT other
> > > than the fact that HyperNEAT (like any machine learning algorithm)
> > > will undoubtedly sometimes need to be applied to a domain that is
> > > best modeled by a surrogate. It appears I am unlikely to see the
> > > deeper connection so perhaps it is not important to belabor it
> > > further. It is very possible others have internalized your point
> > > better and that your efforts at promoting your view will therefore
> > > lead to productive explorations.
> > >
> > > In any case, at least we are agreed that challenges remain in all
> > of
> > > machine learning, including for HyperNEAT. The exciting
> > opportunity
> > > is to meet these challenges with new ideas. Perhaps novel
> > > hybridizations will answer some challenges; perhaps in other cases
> > it
> > > will be something else. What is great for all of us is that by
> > > pursuing the paths we individually favor, even if they differ, we
> > are
> > > expanding the diversity of options for everyone in the future. So
> > > let us encourage each other to follow our instincts to their most
> > > promising ends.
> > >
> > > ken
> > >
> > > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com>, 
> "afcarl2" <a.carl@> wrote:
> > > >
> > > > To the motivated and intellectually honest, I contend that prior
> > > > references and explanations are sufficient for discovery and
> > > > understanding.
> > > >
> > > > That said, no reference has been made to disfavor discovery of
> > > > patterns. In the context of engineering optimization/search, your
> > > > predisposition and creation of hyperneat could be viewed as the
> > > > analogous equivalent of seeking a physics-based surrogate model,
> > > > though for differing reasons.
> > > >
> > > > Perhaps within the confines of your area of expertise, this
> > concept
> > > > is novel, as it appears from your statements. But in the larger
> > > > landscape of engineering optimization/search, there is an entire
> > > > branch of research associated with surrogate-based models and
> > > > optimization/search. Which, btw, if you take the opportunity to
> > > > review what the other guys are doing outside of your area of
> > > > expertise (i.e. previously provided reference), I believe it may
> > > even
> > > > facilitate your endeavors. And at the very least, it would help
> > to
> > > > convey an impression of genuine motivation to discover, rather
> > than
> > > > a "not invented here" mentality.
> > > >
> > > > It is difficult to see the utility of expending the energy of
> > > > explanation, when it appears that you are entangled in the
> > > conflicts
> > > > and differences of opinions within the differing niches of AI,
> > > seemly
> > > > unable to take a step back to get a perspective which includes
> > more
> > > > than these differing niches.
> > > >
> > > > In a nutshell:
> > > > a) Multi-discipline: seemly self-evident, simultaneous or staged,
> > > > analogous to multiple differing vocabularies and syntax.
> > > > b) Multi-Objective: simultaneous, multiple arbitrary hyperspaces
> > of
> > > > arbitrary sub-sets of input parameter dimensionalities.
> > > > c) Linear equality/inequality feasibility constraints: seemly
> > self-
> > > > evident, multiple arbitrary discrete values and/or ranges of
> > > > acceptable values of arbitrary input parameters.
> > > > d) Non-linear equality/inequality feasibility constraints:
> > multiple
> > > > arbitrary discrete values and/or ranges of acceptable values of
> > > > multiple arbitrary hyperspaces of arbitrary sub-sets of input
> > > > parameter dimensionalities.
> > > >
> > > > That said, your predisposition of endeavor appears to be the
> > > > discovery of a global pattern (with or w/o
> > variation/elaboration),
> > > > associated with a given objective hyperspace.
> > > >
> > > > The fundamental problem is that, subsequent to whatever means are
> > > > utilized to apply the arbitrary feasibility constraints (i.e. "c"
> > > > and "d" above), what's left of the given objective function
> > > > landscape "as-delivered" to the EA process, will be difficult or
> > > > perhaps impossible to identify a global pattern of the specific
> > > > objective (i.e. "ARBITRARY" feasibility constraints).
> > > >
> > > > The issue then becomes one of economy. How much computational
> > > > resources should be expended for the sole purpose of discovery of
> > > > a "GLOBAL" pattern (w/ or w/o variation/elaboration) of a given
> > > > objective of a multi-objective problem?
> > > >
> > > > It soon becomes evident that it is more computationally feasible
> > to
> > > > accept "REGIONAL" patterns/correlations/curve-fits.
> > > >
> > > > This is one of the reasons there is an entire research area
> > > > associated w/ surrogate-based models and optimization/search. In
> > > your
> > > > field you appear to refer to it as "representation".
> > > >
> > > > No reference has been made to disfavor use or applicability of EA
> > > for
> > > > determination of pareto front solution sets. On the contrary,
> > they
> > > > are favored and well suited for this application. The issue was
> > > that
> > > > the computational resources required for pareto front
> > determination
> > > > only magnifies/multiplies the computational costs issues
> > associated
> > > > with EA methodologies.
> > > >
> > > > Furthermore, it is self-evident that the application of a given
> > set
> > > > of weights to a multiobjective problem to transform it to a mono-
> > > > objective problem (i.e. NEAT), the solution of which constitutes
> > > only
> > > > a single point of a pareto front solution set.
> > > >
> > > > Simply put, the utility of stove-pipe focus on discovery of
> > global
> > > > patterns on mono-objective problems w/o application of arbitrary
> > > > feasibility constraints is marginal at best. And inapplicable to
> > > real
> > > > world problems at worst.
> > > >
> > > > IMHO, I believe your endevor associated with "representation",
> > > would
> > > > be well served by a review of surrogate-based
> > > > models/optimization/search. But then, that may not be considered
> > > > a "breakthrough".
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com>, 
> "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@> wrote:
> > > > >
> > > > > Andy, maybe you can provide an example of "non-linear
> > inequality
> > > > > feasibility constraints" that "utterly destroy" patterns and
> > > > > regularities?
> > > > >
> > > > > I think most people would agree that many practical problems
> > > > involve
> > > > > some kind of pattern. The human brain itself is filled with
> > > > > spectacular examples of neural patterns, both spatially and
> > > > > temporally. Is the human brain "utterly destroyed" by "non-
> > > linear
> > > > > inequality feasibility constraints?"
> > > > >
> > > > > I get your broader point, though. You're saying that I'm
> > getting
> > > a
> > > > > distorted perspective because I'm conentrating on patterns when
> > > > > there are other factors in the world than just patterns. Yet
> > we
> > > > > cannot expect every new algorithm to simultaneously address
> > every
> > > > > challenge faced by man. Any researcher who would try to do
> > that
> > > > > would never get anywhere. With HyperNEAT we have taken a step
> > in
> > > a
> > > > > promising direction; no more, no less. If you feel it should
> > be
> > > > > expanded to take into account additional particular concerns
> > that
> > > > > you have (which for me are still fuzzy), I encourage you to
> > > extend
> > > > > it in that direction.
> > > > >
> > > > > I think your quote from Einstein is delivered in entirely the
> > > wrong
> > > > > context. The problem of representation is largely ignored by
> > the
> > > > > machine learning community because it *is* the difficult part.
> > > > > The "thin part of the wood" is the minutia of gradient
> > > > optimization,
> > > > > which have been beaten to death; yet scientists to this day
> > still
> > > > > focus on it intently. The reason they do that is because it's
> > > the
> > > > > easy part, not the hard part. It is easy to climb a hill once
> > > you
> > > > > see it; it is hard to move the hill itself. Representation
> > means
> > > > > moving the hills. I believe Einstein would have no objection
> > to
> > > > > rearranging the intellectual landscape.
> > > > >
> > > > > ken
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com>, 
> "afcarl2" <a.carl@> wrote:
> > > > > >
> > > > > > Ken,
> > > > > >
> > > > > > I can appreciate the need to choose applications "with
> > careful
> > > > > > scrutiny with a sincere belief in their practical
> > > ramifications",
> > > > > but
> > > > > > the simple truth is that your bias for exploring "patterns
> > and
> > > > > > regularities", are utterly destroyed by the application of
> > non-
> > > > > linear
> > > > > > inequality feasibility constraints. Which routinely happens
> > in
> > > > the
> > > > > > domain of engineering optimization/search.
> > > > > >
> > > > > > Your operation without the application of the pressures
> > > > associated
> > > > > > with these pattern destroying influences results in a
> > > unrealistic
> > > > > > perspective on the utility of global pattern exploitation,
> > and
> > > a
> > > > > > failure to address the repercussions of the sometimes
> > seemingly
> > > > > > totally arbitrary nature of enforced feasibility constraints
> > > > > dictated
> > > > > > by real-world problems.
> > > > > >
> > > > > > Until you can simultaneously address the exploitation of
> > > multiple
> > > > > > hyperspace "regional/sub-volume" patterns/regularities
> > overlaid
> > > > > with
> > > > > > multiple arbitrary non-linear inequality feasibility
> > > constraints,
> > > > > in
> > > > > > a computationally practical manner, methodologies such as
> > > > > Hyperneat
> > > > > > will be dispatched as "curiosities" only.
> > > > > >
> > > > > > These kinds of pressures are routinely addressed in the
> > domain
> > > of
> > > > > > engineering optimization/search. Your choice of side-stepping
> > > > > these
> > > > > > influences shapes what infrastructure is and is-not
> > developed,
> > > as
> > > > > has
> > > > > > been adequately addressed in prior posts.
> > > > > >
> > > > > > An applicable quote: "I have little patience with scientists
> > > who
> > > > > take
> > > > > > a board of wood, look for its thinnest part, and drill a
> > great
> > > > > number
> > > > > > of holes where drilling is easy."--Albert Einstein
> > > > > >
> > > > > > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com>, 
> "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@>
> > > wrote:
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > Andy, I have no problem with the idea of NEAT as a
> > foundation
> > > > > upon
> > > > > > > which to build. That's perfectly aligned with my view that
> > > > > there is
> > > > > > > more yet to accomplish.
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > Let me respond to some of your specific points below.
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com 
> <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com>, "afcarl2" <a.carl@> wrote:
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > The issues you raise, though valid, appear disingenuous
> > for
> > > > > two
> > > > > > > > reasons. First, if you had reviewed the contents and
> > > > > capabilities
> > > > > > of
> > > > > > > > the Dakota toolkit, you would have discovered the issues
> > as
> > > > > being
> > > > > > > > essentially addressed. Second, not intending any
> > > disrespect,
> > > > > from
> > > > > > > > external appearances, your efforts appear directed in
> > other
> > > > > > > > directions than that of addressing your self admitted
> > areas
> > > > of
> > > > > > > > concern.
> > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > From a review of literature on the subject, there is a
> > > common
> > > > > > > > understanding that EA is computationally expensive and
> > slow
> > > > to
> > > > > > > > converge, but robust for global search in problem domains
> > > > with
> > > > > > > > multiple local minima.
> > > > > > > >
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > It really just depends who you are talking about whether
> > > there
> > > > > is a
> > > > > > > "common understanding" about anything in AI. It also
> > depends
> > > > > > whether
> > > > > > > we are talking about the past or the future.
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > For example, it's often said that "neural networks get
> > caught
> > > > on
> > > > > > local
> > > > > > > optima" (and there is indeed a "common understanding" that
> > > they
> > > > > do)
> > > > > > > but when people say that they are almost always only
> > talking
> > > > > about
> > > > > > > backprop, which is just one single neural network learning
> > > > > > algorithm.
> > > > > > > Backprop is not the only way a neural network can learn.
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > The problem is that when we talk about methods in machine
> > > > > learning
> > > > > > we
> > > > > > > often confuse whether we are talking about a *field* or a
> > > > > particular
> > > > > > > method. In the case of EAs, you seem to be talking about
> > some
> > > > > > > existing methods that have been analyzed (often by people
> > who
> > > > > are
> > > > > > not
> > > > > > > even aware of the most modern approaches) in the past.
> > For
> > > > > > example,
> > > > > > > the old-fashioned bit-string based simple EA has been
> > analyzed
> > > > > > > extensively.
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > Yet as a field, EAs themselves are evolving. Problems
> > > > > identified in
> > > > > > > the past are actively being addressed in the present and
> > > > future.
> > > > > > Some
> > > > > > > modern approaches completely overturn the assumptions and
> > > > > problems
> > > > > > of
> > > > > > > the past (and of course introduce their own new problems).
> > > > > Check
> > > > > > out
> > > > > > > Estimation of Distribution Algorithms and the CMA-ES:
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > >
> > > > 
> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Estimation_of_distribution_algorithm 
> <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Estimation_of_distribution_algorithm>
> > > > > > > http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CMA-ES 
> <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CMA-ES>
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > When I look at EAs, or any research area for that matter, I
> > > > > always
> > > > > > > think about what they *could* be, rather than what they
> > are.
> > > > > And
> > > > > > as a
> > > > > > > researcher, I try to make them what they could be. To me,
> > > that
> > > > > is
> > > > > > the
> > > > > > > exciting thing about research: At its best, it overturns
> > > > dogma.
> > > > > I
> > > > > > > like to view a limitation as a challenge rather than as a
> > > brick
> > > > > > wall.
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > And that is from people who are working "hard" problems
> > > (i.e.
> > > > > > multi-
> > > > > > > > discipline, multiobjective, non-linear inequality
> > > > constraints,
> > > > > > etc.),
> > > > > > > > at government laboratories and Fortune 100 defense firms.
> > > Not
> > > > > > dancing
> > > > > > > > rag-dolls and computer-aided art.
> > > > > > > >
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > First, while you often cite multiobjective optimization as
> > > > > a "hard
> > > > > > > problem" for EAs, in fact some of the most effective
> > > algorithms
> > > > > in
> > > > > > > multiobjective optimization are EAs. EAs are naturally
> > > suited
> > > > to
> > > > > > > maintaining a pareto front because a pareto front requires a
> > > > > > > population to hold it. There is vast literature on pareto
> > > > > > > optimization in EAs, both in multiobjective optimization
> > and
> > > in
> > > > > > > coevolution. Here are some seminal examples:
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > K. Deb, A. Pratap, S. Agarwal, and T. Meyarivan. A Fast and
> > > > > Elitist
> > > > > > > Multiobjective Genetic Algorithm: NSGA-II. IEEE
> > Transactions
> > > on
> > > > > > > Evolutionary Computation, 6(2):182--197, 2002.
> > > > > > > http://citeseer.ist.psu.edu/530140.html 
> <http://citeseer.ist.psu.edu/530140.html>
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > De Jong, E.D. (2004). The Incremental Pareto-Coevolution
> > > > Archive.
> > > > > > > Proceedings of the Genetic and Evolutionary Computation
> > > > > Conference
> > > > > > > GECCO-04, pp. 525-536.
> > > > > > > http://people.cs.uu.nl/dejong/publications/gecco04coev.pdf 
> <http://people.cs.uu.nl/dejong/publications/gecco04coev.pdf>
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > in fact, some of the most brilliant theorists in pareto
> > > > > optimization
> > > > > > > are in evolutionary computation.
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > As for NEAT in government research labs on "serious"
> > > problems,
> > > > > here
> > > > > > is
> > > > > > > an example:
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > Shimon Whiteson and Daniel Whiteson (2007). "Stochastic
> > > > > Optimization
> > > > > > > for Collision Selection in High Energy Physics". IAAI 2007:
> > > > > > > Proceedings of the Nineteenth Annual Innovative
> > Applications
> > > of
> > > > > > > Artificial Intelligence Conference. 
> > > > > > > http://arxiv.org/PS_cache/hep-ex/pdf/0607/0607012v1.pdf 
> <http://arxiv.org/PS_cache/hep-ex/pdf/0607/0607012v1.pdf>
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > The article itself states, "These NEAT selectors are
> > > currently
> > > > > in
> > > > > > use
> > > > > > > at FermiLab for selecting collisions from real data
> > collected
> > > > > > > with the Tevatron collider." So, there you go, NEAT is
> > being
> > > > > used
> > > > > > at
> > > > > > > FermiLab itself to select which particle collisions are
> > most
> > > > > > promising.
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > When you mention rag dolls and art, you're giving me an
> > > > > opportunity
> > > > > > to
> > > > > > > comment on some of our own current research. Our group has
> > > > > indeed
> > > > > > > recently produced a number of works in interactive
> > evolution,
> > > > > > > including dance, art, music, and particle effects. Perhaps
> > > it
> > > > > may
> > > > > > > seem a somewhat lighthearted departure from more serious
> > > > > subjects.
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > Yet the implications of this work are as serious as any in
> > my
> > > > > view.
> > > > > > > All of that work is a probe of the ubiquity of patterns and
> > > > > > > regularities, in particular through the theory of CPPNs.
> > The
> > > > > deeper
> > > > > > > lesson in that body of work is that the very same encoding
> > is
> > > > > able
> > > > > > to
> > > > > > > produce patterns appropriate to what would otherwise appear
> > > to
> > > > be
> > > > > > > disparate domains. The idea is to develop a theory of
> > > generic
> > > > > > pattern
> > > > > > > generation and to show that patterns are interchangeable
> > > across
> > > > > many
> > > > > > > domains. That insight leads to the idea of HyperNEAT,
> > which
> > > > > takes
> > > > > > > again the very same encoding that is producing art and
> > music
> > > > and
> > > > > > uses
> > > > > > > it to produce a large-scale neural pattern. Therein it
> > > becomes
> > > > > > > serious, because the hard problems you like to focus on
> > > almost
> > > > > > always
> > > > > > > involve patterns and regularities.
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > It is no accident that in building a theory of pattern
> > > > > generation, a
> > > > > > > number of interactive evolutionary computation experiments
> > > > would
> > > > > > need
> > > > > > > to be performed because understanding the capabilities of a
> > > > > pattern
> > > > > > > generator require *exploring* the space of possibilities
> > > rather
> > > > > than
> > > > > > > simply optimizing, and humans are much better explorers than
> > > > > > > computers. The theory would never have gotten off the
> > ground
> > > > if
> > > > > we
> > > > > > > had stuck to more traditional optimization problems.
> > > Indeed,
> > > > as
> > > > > > > funny as it sounds, the whole idea began to materialize
> > only
> > > > > after I
> > > > > > > evolved a spaceship in Mattias Fagerlund's DelphiNEAT.
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > To put it starkly, without that exploration in genetic art,
> > > > there
> > > > > > > would have been no HyperNEAT. And in fact even more new
> > > > > theories
> > > > > > with
> > > > > > > practical implications are coming (not yet published)
> > because
> > > of
> > > > > > > phenomena that became apparent through Picbreeder. So you
> > > see,
> > > > > in
> > > > > > > building a new algorithm or a new theory with practical
> > > > > > implications,
> > > > > > > often traditional problems are exactly the wrong vehicle to
> > > > > > discovery
> > > > > > > because they perpetuate the same dogmatic perspectives that
> > > > > already
> > > > > > > permeate the field to begin with and cause it to be staying
> > > in
> > > > > one
> > > > > > > place. Thus all of these applications are chosen with
> > > careful
> > > > > > > scrutiny with a sincere belief in their practical
> > > ramifications.
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > Not to mention the fact that interactive evolution itself
> > has
> > > > the
> > > > > > > practical potential to change the way we do engineering in
> > > some
> > > > > > cases.
> > > > > > > Can you imagine Picbreeder for furinute instead of
> > > pictures?
> > > > > Or
> > > > > > for
> > > > > > > cars? Someday that may be how we create highly customized
> > > > > > artifacts.
> > > > > > > In fact, some of the problems to which you are referring
> > > > > (highly
> > > > > > > nonlinear and multi-objective) may only be possible to
> > solve
> > > > > through
> > > > > > > interactive evolution.
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > How many times has NEAT, as a monolithic approach, been
> > > cited
> > > > > and
> > > > > > > > successfully applied by government laboratories and
> > Fortune
> > > > > 100
> > > > > > > > defense firms for these type of "hard" problems?
> > > > > > > >
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > You can refer to the paper on high-energy physics at
> > FermiLab
> > > if
> > > > > > > you're interested, but I still think there is a bigger
> > > > picture.
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > In some ways, as researchers in AI, what practitioners are
> > > > using
> > > > > to
> > > > > > > solve hard problems is exactly what we *don't* want to
> > use.
> > > > > After
> > > > > > > all, how is anything ever going to become more powerful if
> > we
> > > > > just
> > > > > > > look to practitioners to show us what methods we should be
> > > > > using?
> > > > > > As
> > > > > > > researchers, it is our job to give the practitioners *new*
> > > > > options,
> > > > > > > not the other way around.
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > Practitioners are often several steps behind algorithm
> > > > > developers,
> > > > > > and
> > > > > > > with good reason. They often can't afford to take big
> > risks
> > > > and
> > > > > > need
> > > > > > > something practical in the here and now. You will
> > therefore
> > > > > find
> > > > > > > that most cutting-edge algorithms are not in use in
> > industry
> > > or
> > > > > as
> > > > > > > tools in other scientific disciplines at the very moment
> > that
> > > > > they
> > > > > > are
> > > > > > > cutting-edge. Yet someone has to be developing the
> > > algorithms
> > > > > of
> > > > > > the
> > > > > > > future.
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > ken
> > > > > > >
> > > > > >
> > > > >
> > > >
> > >
> >
>
>

Ken,<br>
<br>
Most excellently said.<br>
<br>
<br>
Carl,<br>
<br>
Like Ken, I invite you to put your time/money where your words are.<br>
<br>
<br>
Jim<br>
<br>
<br>
Kenneth Stanley wrote:
<blockquote cite="mid:frsroi+tmrv@..." type="cite">
  <div id="ygrp-text">
  <p>Andy, let me make you a prediction: If you pursue the research<br>
direction that you believe in, and I pursue the one that I believe in,<br>
the world will be a better place than if we all tried to do exactly<br>
the same thing. That is the beauty of research. But the way to make<br>
something happen in research, the way to convince people of a point of<br>
view, is simply to do it. Why not give your theory a shot? By all<br>
means, broadening the applicability of NEAT and HyperNEAT would be<br>
great. If you have a theory on how to do it, you have my full support.<br>
  <br>
ken<br>
  <br>
--- In <a moz-do-not-send="true" href="mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com">neat@yahoogroups.<wbr>com</a>,
"afcarl2" <a class="moz-txt-link-rfc2396E" href="mailto:a.carl@..."><a.carl@...></a> wrote:<br>
><br>
> Ken,<br>
> <br>
> I believe it would be beneficial to others contemplating usage of <br>
> NEAT, to prominently label what your "individually favored"
version <br>
> of NEAT/HyperNEAT is. Namely, unconstrained mono-objective search.
  <br>
> This way it will enable them to more quickly identify if it is <br>
> consistent with there requirements, embrace it or continue looking.<br>
> <br>
> FYI, "physics-based surrogate models" is to surrogate models, what
  <br>
> NEAT is to AI. One part of a much larger whole. Its evident that
you <br>
> did not "see the deeper connection" intended. That's unfortunate, <br>
> since I believe the applicability of NEAT and HyperNEAT would be <br>
> profoundly broadened.<br>
> <br>
> <br>
> --- In <a moz-do-not-send="true"

area <br>
> and <br>

nice <br>
> > paper on the subject:<br>
> > <br>
> > <a moz-do-not-send="true"
 href="http://www.cs.sandia.gov/DAKOTA/papers/OUU_MAO2004.pdf">http://www.cs.<wbr>sandia.gov/<wbr>DAKOTA/papers/<wbr>OUU_MAO2004.<wbr>pdf</a><br>
> > <br>

other <br>

algorithm) <br>

that is <br>
> > best modeled by a surrogate. It appears I am unlikely to see
the <br>
> > deeper connection so perhaps it is not important to belabor
it <br>
> > further. It is very possible others have internalized your
point <br>
> > better and that your efforts at promoting your view will
therefore <br>
> > lead to productive explorations.<br>
> > <br>
> > In any case, at least we are agreed that challenges remain in
all <br>
> of <br>
> > machine learning, including for HyperNEAT. The exciting <br>
> opportunity <br>
> > is to meet these challenges with new ideas. Perhaps novel <br>
> > hybridizations will answer some challenges; perhaps in other
cases <br>
> it <br>
> > will be something else. What is great for all of us is that
by <br>
> > pursuing the paths we individually favor, even if they
differ, we <br>
> are <br>
> > expanding the diversity of options for everyone in the
future. So <br>
> > let us encourage each other to follow our instincts to their
most <br>
> > promising ends. <br>
> > <br>
> > ken<br>
> > <br>
> > --- In <a moz-do-not-send="true"
 href="mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com">neat@yahoogroups.<wbr>com</a>,

> > ><br>
> > > To the motivated and intellectually honest, I contend
that prior <br>
> > > references and explanations are sufficient for discovery
and <br>
> > > understanding.<br>

discovery of <br>
> > > patterns. In the context of engineering optimization/<wbr>search,
your <br>
> > > predisposition and creation of hyperneat could be viewed
as the <br>
> > > analogous equivalent of seeking a physics-based
surrogate model, <br>
> > > though for differing reasons.<br>
> > > <br>

this <br>
> concept <br>
> > > is novel, as it appears from your statements. But in the
larger <br>
> > > landscape of engineering optimization/<wbr>search, there
is an entire <br>
> > > branch of research associated with surrogate-based
models and <br>
> > > optimization/<wbr>search. Which, btw, if you take the
opportunity to <br>

area of <br>
> > > expertise (i.e. previously provided reference), I
believe it may <br>
> > even <br>
> > > facilitate your endeavors. And at the very least, it
would help <br>
> to <br>
> > > convey an impression of genuine motivation to discover,
rather <br>
> than <br>
> > > a "not invented here" mentality.<br>
> > > <br>

energy of <br>
> > > explanation, when it appears that you are entangled in
the <br>
> > conflicts <br>
> > > and differences of opinions within the differing niches
of AI, <br>
> > seemly <br>
> > > unable to take a step back to get a perspective which
includes <br>
> more <br>
> > > than these differing niches.<br>
> > > <br>
> > > In a nutshell:<br>
> > > a) Multi-discipline: seemly self-evident, simultaneous
or staged, <br>
> > > analogous to multiple differing vocabularies and syntax.<br>
> > > b) Multi-Objective: simultaneous, multiple arbitrary
hyperspaces <br>
> of <br>
> > > arbitrary sub-sets of input parameter dimensionalities.<br>
> > > c) Linear equality/inequality feasibility constraints:
seemly <br>
> self-<br>
> > > evident, multiple arbitrary discrete values and/or
ranges of <br>
> > > acceptable values of arbitrary input parameters.<br>
> > > d) Non-linear equality/inequality feasibility
constraints: <br>
> multiple <br>
> > > arbitrary discrete values and/or ranges of acceptable
values of <br>
> > > multiple arbitrary hyperspaces of arbitrary sub-sets of
input <br>
> > > parameter dimensionalities.<br>
> > > <br>
> > > That said, your predisposition of endeavor appears to be
the <br>
> > > discovery of a global pattern (with or w/o <br>
> variation/elaborati<wbr>on), <br>
> > > associated with a given objective hyperspace.<br>
> > > <br>
> > > The fundamental problem is that, subsequent to whatever
means are <br>
> > > utilized to apply the arbitrary feasibility constraints
(i.e. "c" <br>
> > > and "d" above), what's left of the given objective
function <br>
> > > landscape "as-delivered" to the EA process, will be
difficult or <br>
> > > perhaps impossible to identify a global pattern of the
specific <br>
> > > objective (i.e. "ARBITRARY" feasibility constraints)<wbr>.<br>
> > > <br>
> > > The issue then becomes one of economy. How much
computational <br>
> > > resources should be expended for the sole purpose of
discovery of <br>
> > > a "GLOBAL" pattern (w/ or w/o variation/elaborati<wbr>on)
of a given <br>
> > > objective of a multi-objective problem?<br>
> > > <br>
> > > It soon becomes evident that it is more computationally
feasible <br>
> to <br>
> > > accept "REGIONAL" patterns/correlatio<wbr>ns/curve-<wbr>fits.<br>
> > > <br>
> > > This is one of the reasons there is an entire research
area <br>
> > > associated w/ surrogate-based models and optimization/<wbr>search.
In <br>
> > your <br>
> > > field you appear to refer to it as "representation"<wbr>.<br>
> > > <br>
> > > No reference has been made to disfavor use or
applicability of EA <br>
> > for <br>
> > > determination of pareto front solution sets. On the
contrary, <br>
> they <br>
> > > are favored and well suited for this application. The
issue was <br>
> > that <br>
> > > the computational resources required for pareto front <br>
> determination <br>
> > > only magnifies/multiplie<wbr>s the computational costs
issues <br>
> associated <br>
> > > with EA methodologies. <br>
> > > <br>
> > > Furthermore, it is self-evident that the application of
a given <br>
> set <br>
> > > of weights to a multiobjective problem to transform it
to a mono-<br>
> > > objective problem (i.e. NEAT), the solution of which
constitutes <br>
> > only <br>
> > > a single point of a pareto front solution set.<br>
> > > <br>
> > > Simply put, the utility of stove-pipe focus on discovery
of <br>
> global <br>
> > > patterns on mono-objective problems w/o application of
arbitrary <br>
> > > feasibility constraints is marginal at best. And
inapplicable to <br>
> > real <br>
> > > world problems at worst.<br>
> > > <br>
> > > IMHO, I believe your endevor associated with
"representation"<wbr>, <br>
> > would <br>
> > > be well served by a review of surrogate-based <br>
> > > models/optimization<wbr>/search. But then, that may not
be considered <br>
> > > a "breakthrough"<wbr>.<br>
> > > <br>
> > > <br>

> > > > > > <br>
> > > > > > Yet as a field, EAs themselves are
evolving. Problems <br>
> > > > identified in<br>

the present and <br>
> > > future. <br>
> > > > > Some<br>
> > > > > > modern approaches completely overturn the
assumptions and <br>
> > > > problems <br>
> > > > > of<br>

> > > > Check <br>
> > > > > out<br>
> > > > > > Estimation of Distribution Algorithms and
the CMA-ES:<br>
> > > > > > <br>
> > > > > > <br>
> > > <a moz-do-not-send="true"
 href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Estimation_of_distribution_algorithm">http://en.wikipedia<wbr>.org/wiki/<wbr>Estimation_<wbr>of_distribution_<wbr>algorithm</a><br>
> > > > > > <a moz-do-not-send="true"
 href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CMA-ES">http://en.wikipedia<wbr>.org/wiki/<wbr>CMA-ES</a><br>
> > > > > > <br>
> > > > > > When I look at EAs, or any research area
for that matter, I <br>
> > > > always<br>
> > > > > > think about what they *could* be, rather
than what they <br>
> are. <br>
> > > > And <br>
> > > > > as a<br>
> > > > > > researcher, I try to make them what they
could be. To me, <br>
> > that <br>
> > > > is <br>
> > > > > the<br>
> > > > > > exciting thing about research: At its
best, it overturns <br>
> > > dogma. <br>
> > > > I<br>
> > > > > > like to view a limitation as a challenge
rather than as a <br>
> > brick <br>
> > > > > wall.<br>
> > > > > > <br>
> > > > > > > And that is from people who are
working "hard" problems <br>
> > (i.e. <br>
> > > > > multi-<br>
> > > > > > > discipline, multiobjective,
non-linear inequality <br>
> > > constraints, <br>
> > > > > etc.), <br>
> > > > > > > at government laboratories and
Fortune 100 defense firms. <br>
> > Not <br>
> > > > > dancing <br>
> > > > > > > rag-dolls and computer-aided art.<br>
> > > > > > > <br>
> > > > > > <br>
> > > > > > First, while you often cite
multiobjective optimization as <br>
> > > > a "hard<br>
> > > > > > problem" for EAs, in fact some of the
most effective <br>
> > algorithms <br>
> > > > in<br>
> > > > > > multiobjective optimization are EAs. EAs
are naturally <br>
> > suited <br>
> > > to<br>
> > > > > > maintaining a pareto front because a
pareto front requires a<br>
> > > > > > population to hold it. There is vast
literature on pareto<br>
> > > > > > optimization in EAs, both in
multiobjective optimization <br>
> and <br>
> > in<br>
> > > > > > coevolution. Here are some seminal
examples:<br>
> > > > > > <br>
> > > > > > K. Deb, A. Pratap, S. Agarwal, and T.
Meyarivan. A Fast and <br>
> > > > Elitist<br>
> > > > > > Multiobjective Genetic Algorithm:
NSGA-II. IEEE <br>
> Transactions <br>
> > on<br>
> > > > > > Evolutionary Computation, 6(2):182–197,
2002.<br>
> > > > > > <a moz-do-not-send="true"
 href="http://citeseer.ist.psu.edu/530140.html">http://citeseer.<wbr>ist.psu.edu/<wbr>530140.html</a><br>
> > > > > > <br>
> > > > > > De Jong, E.D. (2004). The Incremental
Pareto-Coevolution <br>
> > > Archive.<br>
> > > > > > Proceedings of the Genetic and
Evolutionary Computation <br>
> > > > Conference<br>
> > > > > > GECCO-04, pp. 525-536. <br>
> > > > > > <a moz-do-not-send="true"
 href="http://people.cs.uu.nl/dejong/publications/gecco04coev.pdf">http://people.<wbr>cs.uu.nl/<wbr>dejong/publicati<wbr>ons/gecco04coev.<wbr>pdf</a><br>
> > > > > > <br>
> > > > > > in fact, some of the most brilliant
theorists in pareto <br>
> > > > optimization<br>
> > > > > > are in evolutionary computation.<br>
> > > > > > <br>
> > > > > > As for NEAT in government research labs
on "serious" <br>
> > problems, <br>
> > > > here <br>
> > > > > is<br>
> > > > > > an example:<br>
> > > > > > <br>
> > > > > > Shimon Whiteson and Daniel Whiteson
(2007). "Stochastic <br>
> > > > Optimization<br>
> > > > > > for Collision Selection in High Energy
Physics". IAAI 2007:<br>
> > > > > > Proceedings of the Nineteenth Annual
Innovative <br>
> Applications <br>
> > of<br>
> > > > > > Artificial Intelligence Conference.&<wbr>#8202;<br>
> > > > > > <a moz-do-not-send="true"
 href="http://arxiv.org/PS_cache/hep-ex/pdf/0607/0607012v1.pdf">http://arxiv.<wbr>org/PS_cache/<wbr>hep-ex/pdf/<wbr>0607/0607012v1.<wbr>pdf</a><br>
> > > > > > <br>
> > > > > > The article itself states, "These NEAT
selectors are <br>
> > currently <br>
> > > > in <br>
> > > > > use<br>
> > > > > > at FermiLab for selecting collisions from
real data <br>
> collected<br>
> > > > > > with the Tevatron collider." So, there
you go, NEAT is <br>
> being <br>
> > > > used <br>
> > > > > at<br>
> > > > > > FermiLab itself to select which particle
collisions are <br>
> most <br>
> > > > > promising.<br>
> > > > > > <br>
> > > > > > When you mention rag dolls and art,
you're giving me an <br>
> > > > opportunity <br>
> > > > > to<br>
> > > > > > comment on some of our own current
research. Our group has <br>
> > > > indeed<br>
> > > > > > recently produced a number of works in
interactive <br>
> evolution,<br>
> > > > > > including dance, art, music, and particle
effects. Perhaps <br>
> > it <br>
> > > > may<br>
> > > > > > seem a somewhat lighthearted departure
from more serious <br>
> > > > subjects.<br>
> > > > > > <br>
> > > > > > Yet the implications of this work are as
serious as any in <br>
> my <br>
> > > > view. <br>
> > > > > > All of that work is a probe of the
ubiquity of patterns and<br>
> > > > > > regularities, in particular through the
theory of CPPNs. <br>
> The <br>
> > > > deeper<br>
> > > > > > lesson in that body of work is that the
very same encoding <br>
> is <br>
> > > > able <br>
> > > > > to<br>
> > > > > > produce patterns appropriate to what
would otherwise appear <br>
> > to <br>
> > > be<br>
> > > > > > disparate domains. The idea is to develop
a theory of <br>
> > generic <br>
> > > > > pattern<br>
> > > > > > generation and to show that patterns are
interchangeable <br>
> > across <br>
> > > > many<br>
> > > > > > domains. That insight leads to the idea
of HyperNEAT, <br>
> which <br>
> > > > takes<br>
> > > > > > again the very same encoding that is
producing art and <br>
> music <br>
> > > and <br>
> > > > > uses<br>
> > > > > > it to produce a large-scale neural
pattern. Therein it <br>
> > becomes<br>
> > > > > > serious, because the hard problems you
like to focus on <br>
> > almost <br>
> > > > > always<br>
> > > > > > involve patterns and regularities. <br>
> > > > > > <br>
> > > > > > It is no accident that in building a
theory of pattern <br>
> > > > generation, a<br>
> > > > > > number of interactive evolutionary
computation experiments <br>
> > > would <br>
> > > > > need<br>
> > > > > > to be performed because understanding the
capabilities of a <br>
> > > > pattern<br>
> > > > > > generator require *exploring* the space
of possibilities <br>
> > rather <br>
> > > > than<br>
> > > > > > simply optimizing, and humans are much
better explorers than<br>
> > > > > > computers. The theory would never have
gotten off the <br>
> ground <br>
> > > if <br>
> > > > we<br>
> > > > > > had stuck to more traditional
optimization problems. <br>
> > Indeed, <br>
> > > as<br>
> > > > > > funny as it sounds, the whole idea began
to materialize <br>
> only <br>
> > > > after I<br>
> > > > > > evolved a spaceship in Mattias
Fagerlund's DelphiNEAT. <br>
> > > > > > <br>
> > > > > > To put it starkly, without that
exploration in genetic art, <br>
> > > there<br>
> > > > > > would have been no HyperNEAT. And in fact
even more new <br>
> > > > theories <br>
> > > > > with<br>
> > > > > > practical implications are coming (not
yet published) <br>
> because <br>
> > of<br>
> > > > > > phenomena that became apparent through
Picbreeder. So you <br>
> > see, <br>
> > > > in<br>
> > > > > > building a new algorithm or a new theory
with practical <br>
> > > > > implications,<br>
> > > > > > often traditional problems are exactly
the wrong vehicle to <br>
> > > > > discovery<br>
> > > > > > because they perpetuate the same dogmatic
perspectives that <br>
> > > > already<br>
> > > > > > permeate the field to begin with and
cause it to be staying <br>
> > in <br>
> > > > one<br>
> > > > > > place. Thus all of these applications are
chosen with <br>
> > careful<br>
> > > > > > scrutiny with a sincere belief in their
practical <br>
> > ramifications.<br>
> > > > > > <br>
> > > > > > Not to mention the fact that interactive
evolution itself <br>
> has <br>
> > > the<br>
> > > > > > practical potential to change the way we
do engineering in <br>
> > some <br>
> > > > > cases.<br>
> > > > > > Can you imagine Picbreeder for furinute
instead of <br>
> > pictures? <br>
> > > > Or <br>
> > > > > for<br>
> > > > > > cars? Someday that may be how we create
highly customized <br>
> > > > > artifacts.<br>
> > > > > > In fact, some of the problems to which
you are referring <br>
> > > > (highly<br>
> > > > > > nonlinear and multi-objective) may only
be possible to <br>
> solve <br>
> > > > through<br>
> > > > > > interactive evolution.<br>
> > > > > > <br>
> > > > > > > How many times has NEAT, as a
monolithic approach, been <br>
> > cited <br>
> > > > and <br>
> > > > > > > successfully applied by government
laboratories and <br>
> Fortune <br>
> > > > 100 <br>
> > > > > > > defense firms for these type of
"hard" problems?<br>
> > > > > > > <br>
> > > > > > <br>
> > > > > > You can refer to the paper on high-energy
physics at <br>
> FermiLab <br>
> > if<br>
> > > > > > you're interested, but I still think
there is a bigger <br>
> > > picture. <br>
> > > > > > <br>
> > > > > > In some ways, as researchers in AI, what
practitioners are <br>
> > > using <br>
> > > > to<br>
> > > > > > solve hard problems is exactly what we
*don't* want to <br>
> use. <br>
> > > > After<br>
> > > > > > all, how is anything ever going to become
more powerful if <br>
> we <br>
> > > > just<br>
> > > > > > look to practitioners to show us what
methods we should be <br>
> > > > using? <br>
> > > > > As<br>
> > > > > > researchers, it is our job to give the
practitioners *new* <br>
> > > > options,<br>
> > > > > > not the other way around.<br>
> > > > > > <br>
> > > > > > Practitioners are often several steps
behind algorithm <br>
> > > > developers, <br>
> > > > > and<br>
> > > > > > with good reason. They often can't afford
to take big <br>
> risks <br>
> > > and <br>
> > > > > need<br>
> > > > > > something practical in the here and now.
You will <br>
> therefore <br>
> > > > find<br>
> > > > > > that most cutting-edge algorithms are not
in use in <br>
> industry <br>
> > or <br>
> > > > as<br>
> > > > > > tools in other scientific disciplines at
the very moment <br>
> that <br>
> > > > they <br>
> > > > > are<br>
> > > > > > cutting-edge. Yet someone has to be
developing the <br>
> > algorithms <br>
> > > > of <br>
> > > > > the<br>
> > > > > > future.<br>
> > > > > > <br>
> > > > > > ken<br>
> > > > > ><br>
> > > > ><br>
> > > ><br>
> > ><br>
> ><br>
><br>
  <br>
  </p>
